quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You have to deliberately not act on the feedback of many of your early users, and this is at the same time as listening to people intensely and building what people want.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product-market-fit guidance: listen deeply, but be highly selective about which early feedback you act on.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: That's what we're here to do, is to make something that people want, but it can't be all people.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A crisp reminder that strong products are built for a specific audience, not everyone—useful for focus and positioning decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This is a technique that I call the switch lock. It's born out of the observation that your calendar says what you thought you were going to do, but it's really only your trail of work that describes what you actually did. How can we capture that?
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Introduces a practical time-allocation framework: measure real work done (trail of work) rather than planned work (calendar).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I learned the real secret behind virality. There is no such thing as a truly viral product.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Challenges the common “build virality” narrative, setting up a more grounded view of growth mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and understanding the performance of new features, and Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo ad read)
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth methodology and emphasizes speed + rigor as the key levers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo ad read)
quotes.context: Actionable claim that better stats and tooling can materially reduce iteration cycles on experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo ad read)
quotes.context: Introduces the “A/B testing flywheel” mental model: sharing learnings compounds future experiment ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Full disclosure, real estate investing is boring.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Fundrise ad read)
quotes.context: Counterintuitive framing that “boring” can be a feature (less noise, more long-term focus) in investing.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The fund holds $1.1 billion worth of institutional caliber real estate managed by team of pros focused on steadily growing your net worth for decades to come.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Fundrise ad read)
quotes.context: Concrete data point plus a long-horizon approach (“decades”) as the operating model for compounding wealth.

quotes.topic_title: Rapportive acquisition and pivotal career lessons
quotes.text: Rapportive was my last company. It was the first Gmail extension to scale to millions of users.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete example of achieving massive distribution via an extension, highlighting the scale possible with the right integration point.

quotes.topic_title: Rapportive acquisition and pivotal career lessons
quotes.text: It turns out we somehow attracted most of LinkedIn's daily active users onto this one free app, and I then ultimately ended up selling that to LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Illustrates a powerful acquisition lever: owning a surface that captures a large share of a platform’s active users—even as a free product.

quotes.topic_title: Rapportive acquisition and pivotal career lessons
quotes.text: Now, had I known that we'd amassed most of LinkedIn's active users onto one app, I would have sold it for far more.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A negotiation/valuation lesson: accurately quantifying strategic leverage (like user concentration) can materially change outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Rapportive acquisition and pivotal career lessons
quotes.text: Because I reported to LinkedIn's head of Growth, Elliot Shmukler. He was responsible for scaling LinkedIn from 25 million members to when I joined, north of 250 million members.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Provides a specific growth-scale data point and underscores the value of learning directly from proven growth leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Rapportive acquisition and pivotal career lessons
quotes.text: And during my first one-on-one, I learned the real secret behind virality and big hint, it's not about viral mechanics.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges common “viral loop” thinking and points practitioners toward deeper drivers of virality.

quotes.topic_title: Virality myth: mechanics vs word of mouth
quotes.text: "Okay. Well, hate to burst your bubble, but there is no such thing as a truly viral product."
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing that challenges the common assumption that breakout growth comes from sustained virality.

quotes.topic_title: Virality myth: mechanics vs word of mouth
quotes.text: "What I mean is, no app has sustained a viral factor of greater than one for any real period of time."
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A practical benchmark for growth teams: don’t plan on viral loops compounding indefinitely.

quotes.topic_title: Virality myth: mechanics vs word of mouth
quotes.text: "Even Facebook in its heyday had a viral factor of about 0.7."
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete data point that resets expectations for what “incredible” virality looks like in reality.

quotes.topic_title: Virality myth: mechanics vs word of mouth
quotes.text: "So even that feature had a lifetime viral factor of about 0.4, and that's considered good."
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A specific example showing that even famous viral mechanics (like address book import) often produce modest, non-compounding results.

quotes.topic_title: Virality myth: mechanics vs word of mouth
quotes.text: "It is word of mouth. It is the virality you can't measure that isn't a mechanic that isn't in a feature. It is when one user spontaneously tells another user about your product."
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A clear mental model for focusing on the hardest-to-measure but most durable driver of growth: organic, spontaneous recommendations.

quotes.topic_title: Whales, referrals, and making email collaborative
quotes.text: Yeah, we've definitely found that there are whales, to use the gaming terminology, that one person is going to be responsible for inviting 25, 50, 100 people, and they may have various motivations for doing that.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A practical mental model for “virality”: a small number of high-leverage users (“whales”) drive outsized referrals, so design and measurement should account for power-law behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Whales, referrals, and making email collaborative
quotes.text: We have people who send many, many hundreds of invites and there are some people who essentially have free Superhuman for life now due to how many people they've invited.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how strong referral incentives can create extreme outcomes (hundreds of invites; free-for-life users), useful for calibrating referral economics.

quotes.topic_title: Whales, referrals, and making email collaborative
quotes.text: But of course that incentive doesn't necessarily work inside of a company or inside of a team where ultimately it's the company paying for the product, so you have to then come up with new motivations for those people.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market insight: incentives that work for individual buyers often fail in B2B/team contexts, requiring different motivation design.

quotes.topic_title: Whales, referrals, and making email collaborative
quotes.text: That's where there really isn't any substitute to having a genuinely multiplayer or a genuinely collaborative product.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A product strategy principle: for team adoption, collaboration isn’t a nice-to-have growth lever—it can be the core mechanism that replaces incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Whales, referrals, and making email collaborative
quotes.text: It turns out they're not actually spreading in this exponential way, there's one person that spreads it to a lot of people and it keeps happening.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that challenges the common “exponential virality” narrative and reframes growth as repeated one-to-many events.

quotes.topic_title: Baking remarkableness into company values
quotes.text: People talk about all these viral features and sharing contact books and all these things. And your point is, that takes you to a place, but really what helps a consumer-ish product spread is word of mouth, people sharing with each other.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Challenges the common focus on built-in virality by emphasizing word-of-mouth as the primary growth driver for consumer products.

quotes.topic_title: Baking remarkableness into company values
quotes.text: There's actually another way, which is simply creating something remarkable, and you used that word, and that is one of the core values of Superhuman.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Introduces a simple growth model: instead of engineering sharing mechanics, make the product inherently remarkable.

quotes.topic_title: Baking remarkableness into company values
quotes.text: We have, create delight, create something that is so joyful that really truly brings people delight.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Offers an actionable product bar—optimize for genuine delight as a driver of retention and advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: Baking remarkableness into company values
quotes.text: We have deliver remarkable quality, something that is so striking, so compelling and worthy of attention that people can't but help tell others about it.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Defines “remarkable quality” in practical terms: build something attention-worthy that naturally triggers sharing.

quotes.topic_title: Baking remarkableness into company values
quotes.text: That's another trick, which is literally baking these raw ingredients for growth into your company values.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A methodology for scaling product quality: encode growth drivers directly into company values so teams execute them consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing slowdown: market widening vs deepening
quotes.text: I think to break this down, it's important to start by defining what we mean by a slowdown. There's the kind of slowdown that is unavoidable in certain spaces, and then there is the kind of slowdown that is quite avoidable.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Introduces a practical diagnostic split that helps teams distinguish structural constraints from fixable execution issues.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing slowdown: market widening vs deepening
quotes.text: So starting with unavoidable slowdown, you can classify anything that you build in a company into one of two categories, solution deepening and market widening.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Provides a simple, reusable taxonomy for prioritization and explaining why shipping may “feel” slower.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing slowdown: market widening vs deepening
quotes.text: Whereas market widening means making your product available to more users, but not making the product itself any better.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Clarifies a counterintuitive tradeoff: growth work can consume effort without improving the core experience for current users.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing slowdown: market widening vs deepening
quotes.text: But this is the hard part, when you're doing that market widening, you're not solution deepening, so your perceived product velocity may decrease.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Explains why teams can appear to slow down even while making strategically necessary investments.

quotes.topic_title: Diagnosing slowdown: market widening vs deepening
quotes.text: You can avoid some of these things with some smart technology decisions, but mostly you just have to grind through it, and it is worth it to get to the other side.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for leaders: accept and plan for the grind phase of platform expansion rather than misdiagnosing it as poor performance.

quotes.topic_title: Org redesign to regain speed and focus
quotes.text: No CEO ever gets their executive team right on the first try.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A blunt expectation-setter that normalizes exec churn and encourages designing systems that can absorb inevitable leadership changes.

quotes.topic_title: Org redesign to regain speed and focus
quotes.text: At one point I noticed I was spending six to 7% of my week on these areas, these areas where I can truly be world-class at.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how CEO time can drift away from highest-leverage work—and why measuring it can trigger redesign.

quotes.topic_title: Org redesign to regain speed and focus
quotes.text: as CEO, once you get to a certain scale, and we were definitely at that scale, you can actually define what you want the role of a CEO to be at your company.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A framework for intentionally shaping the CEO role instead of inheriting a default, conventional job description.

quotes.topic_title: Org redesign to regain speed and focus
quotes.text: What I did is, I hired a really great president, I went from eight direct reports to two, and the amount of time that I spend on product design, technology and marketing went up from six to 7% to about 60% to 70% of my week.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A specific org redesign play (hire a president, slash direct reports) tied to a measurable outcome in CEO focus time.

quotes.topic_title: Org redesign to regain speed and focus
quotes.text: you think it's going to speed up, but it slows down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that adding layers of delegation/executives can reduce velocity rather than increase it.

quotes.topic_title: Switch log time tracking and context switching
quotes.text: This is a technique that I call the Switch log. It's born out of the observation that your calendar says what you thought you were going to do, but it's really only your trail of work that describes what you actually did.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Defines a practical framework for measuring real work (task switches) instead of relying on calendar intent.

quotes.topic_title: Switch log time tracking and context switching
quotes.text: What if every single time I change task I just Slack DM'd my EA, but this also works in Slackbot, it just has to go somewhere. I Slack DM'd my EA and I said, "TS:," and then a few words for the task I was doing.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Gives an immediately implementable method for lightweight time/context tracking with minimal overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Switch log time tracking and context switching
quotes.text: What I'm saying is, do what feels right for as long as it feels right to do. Then at the end of the week you can see where your time is going.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Counterintuitively encourages flexible task choice while using weekly logs to audit outcomes rather than forcing calendar adherence.

quotes.topic_title: Switch log time tracking and context switching
quotes.text: I realized at one point that I was spending only in those days 5% of my time on recruiting, whereas perhaps I should be spending 20 or 30% or more of my time on recruiting.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Concrete data point showing how the Switch log reveals misallocation between actual vs desired leadership priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Switch log time tracking and context switching
quotes.text: There's definitely this idea that, for every interruption you have, the brain does take roughly 21 minutes on average to recover, to get back to the efficacy before that you were disturbed.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Memorable metric that quantifies the cost of interruptions and motivates designing workflows/tools to reduce disruption.

quotes.topic_title: Transcendental meditation for performance and creativity
quotes.text: I do about half an hour in the morning, including rest time. The physical rest component of it is very important to me. So it's 20 minutes of the actual meditation, then 10 minutes of rest. I do that in the morning as well as in the afternoon at around 3:00 PM
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Gives a precise, repeatable TM protocol (including the often-missed rest period) and a concrete scheduling example.

quotes.topic_title: Transcendental meditation for performance and creativity
quotes.text: They also know that nothing can override this TM block. Without it I genuinely start to fall apart. But with it, I'm able to access some very deep competencies that I didn't have before.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization rule: treat meditation as non-negotiable because it unlocks higher-leverage capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Transcendental meditation for performance and creativity
quotes.text: I've been doing this now for about four or five years, and initially I simply felt happier, occasionally even more euphoric coming out of a really great meditation session. But over time I found that my ability to focus was increasing. I could hold attention on something for much longer, but I also was able to become much more creative and much more expressive.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Describes a time-based progression of benefits (mood first, then focus/creativity/expression) that helps set expectations for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Transcendental meditation for performance and creativity
quotes.text: Absolutely, a lot. But in summary, have a coach teach you. I had many false starts myself with meditation, trying the various apps, learning from books. None of it really worked for me. What worked was having one-on-one teaching from someone themselves who had been taught one-on-one the Yogic or the Raja tradition of teaching.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Actionable learning methodology: skip self-serve approaches if they stall and invest in 1:1 instruction for better adherence and results.

quotes.topic_title: Transcendental meditation for performance and creativity
quotes.text: And interestingly about TM, if you compare it to other forms of meditation, they don't have quite the same impact across quite as many executive functions.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A provocative comparative claim that challenges the assumption that all meditation styles produce similar cognitive outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: President role as operational co-founder substitute
quotes.text: The biggest thing was taking off the operations and the management of the executive team and the rest of the company.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Defines the core scope of the president role as an explicit lever to reclaim founder time and focus.

quotes.topic_title: President role as operational co-founder substitute
quotes.text: Think of the president role in Superhuman as an operationally extremely challenging and a very growthful role. It is perfect for someone who wants to go on to be a CEO in their next role.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Offers a practical hiring lens: position the role as a CEO-training ground to attract the right caliber of operator.

quotes.topic_title: President role as operational co-founder substitute
quotes.text: In addition, because that's not the only job, in addition, they're also a very strong thought partner when it comes to corporate strategy.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Expands the role beyond execution into strategic leverage, clarifying why it can substitute for a co-founder dynamic.

quotes.topic_title: President role as operational co-founder substitute
quotes.text: Another way to think about it is, it's almost like a grown-up co-founder.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for when/why to add a president: to restore co-founder-level energy and leverage in a mature company.

quotes.topic_title: President role as operational co-founder substitute
quotes.text: One is just, it's cool the solution to helping you move faster and do the work you want to do is org design.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that speed and founder satisfaction can be solved structurally (org design), not just by working harder.

quotes.topic_title: Attention to detail: funding story and typography
quotes.text: The first thing we did was, we took our UI and we laid it out in about 15 different styles using examples of the major font families. We actually printed these out and we left them on a desk in the middle of our office. Sometimes with design, you want to tune in to your immediate most visceral response, but sometimes you want to truly let a design marinate. And this was the latter. So we let these designs marinate, we let these font choices percolate.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete design methodology: compare many options, make them physically present, and evaluate over time rather than relying on first impressions.

quotes.topic_title: Attention to detail: funding story and typography
quotes.text: Number one, I was looking for a font that was in and of itself gorgeous. Number two, I was looking for a font that could also convey a message of any kind, without overpowering the sentiment of that message. For example, does the font work when this is inviting you to a party? Many fonts, including almost all serif fonts, are actually too somber or too sober for that. Or to pick another extreme, does the font work if it is informing you of somebody's passing, many fonts are just too jaunty for that. You wouldn't want that kind of message in Comic Sans, for example. And number three, I was optimizing for a font that made reading speed and comprehension really fast. And number four, I was looking for a font that made email addresses themselves look great.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A practical 4-part rubric for choosing typography that balances aesthetics, emotional tone range, readability, and domain-specific rendering needs.

quotes.topic_title: Attention to detail: funding story and typography
quotes.text: The problem with really wide and really long lines, is that they decrease reading speed. Because by the time you've reached the end of one line, your eyes have lost track of the start of the next line.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive UX insight: more screen width can harm readability, so constrain line length to improve speed and comprehension.

quotes.topic_title: Attention to detail: funding story and typography
quotes.text: So at Superhuman we, if you've used the product, you know this, we fix the line length or the typographical measure to the optimal length for reading speed, which depending on the font is around 90 to 120 characters.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A specific, actionable design parameter (90–120 characters per line) practitioners can apply to optimize reading speed.

quotes.topic_title: Attention to detail: funding story and typography
quotes.text: We'd probably had about 10, 15 users at the time.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A memorable example of investing in craft (customizing typography) extremely early—before product-market proof.

quotes.topic_title: Craft vs speed: when polish matters pre-launch
quotes.text: How much to spend time ahead of launch really does depend on the markets and the structure, the nature of your business model.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A clear decision rule: pre-launch polish vs. speed should be determined by market dynamics and business model, not generic startup advice.

quotes.topic_title: Craft vs speed: when polish matters pre-launch
quotes.text: That's when there's no time to spare, that's when you probably shouldn't even be sleeping. You're going to hire the most aggressive maniacal people possible. You're going to work 120-hour weeks, because every marginal minute actually does matter. Every marginal minute in the market, growing compounding is going to make your next year even better.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A vivid, actionable model for network-effect races: prioritize speed aggressively because time compounds into durable advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Craft vs speed: when polish matters pre-launch
quotes.text: That's actually not true of all startups and it certainly isn't true of something like Superhuman.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A contrarian correction to “move fast” dogma: not all products/markets reward maximal speed the same way.

quotes.topic_title: Craft vs speed: when polish matters pre-launch
quotes.text: That's why when you have mission-critical products like email where you are interfacing with customers, with candidates, with investors, it turns out to really matter. Email is mission-critical. It's not something where you can simply launch with a half-baked product.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A practical threshold for quality: if failures create reputational damage in high-stakes workflows, reliability must come before shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Craft vs speed: when polish matters pre-launch
quotes.text: Now he goes back into his Gmail, he sees that yes, actually the original emails that were queued up in mailbox have now indeed been sent, and some of the investors, and unfortunately most of the investors he actually pitched twice.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete failure story illustrating how “mostly works” can backfire in mission-critical products through delayed/duplicated actions.

quotes.topic_title: Positioning Superhuman around speed
quotes.text: Bill is right and I agree with him, you have to pick something. Knowing what to pick is the trick.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concise positioning principle: differentiation requires committing to a single lever, and the hard part is choosing the right one.

quotes.topic_title: Positioning Superhuman around speed
quotes.text: So in order for Superhuman to be memorable, I believed that we needed to occupy a clear position that was unique and which was available and which reinforced our product strategy.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A practical positioning checklist: clear, unique, available, and aligned with product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Positioning Superhuman around speed
quotes.text: In the first year of Superhuman, therefore, I interviewed hundreds of potential customers about their experience with Gmail and with Outlook.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for finding positioning: do high-volume customer interviews focused on incumbent alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: Positioning Superhuman around speed
quotes.text: I then asked myself, "Is the position of speed unique and is it available?" And the answer was overwhelmingly yes, because almost no software was being sold or has ever been sold on the value proposition of speed.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that “speed” is an underused value proposition in software, making it a potentially open lane.

quotes.topic_title: Positioning Superhuman around speed
quotes.text: Then finally I did what I call the cocktail party test, which is to look at the cocktail parties and to watch how people pitch your product to other people.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A memorable framework for validating positioning: see if users naturally describe the product with a simple, repeatable pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yes, so we just launched OneSchema of FileFeeds, which allows you to build an integration with any system in 15 minutes, as long as you can export a CSV to an SFTP folder.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A concrete, time-bound promise and constraint that frames a fast path to integrations via CSV-to-SFTP.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We allow our customers to offer thousands of integrations without involving their engineering team at all.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A counterintuitive scaling claim: expanding integrations while removing engineering as the bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've heard so many horror stories of multi-day outages from even just a handful of bad records.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: A vivid reliability lesson that highlights how small data issues can cascade into major operational incidents.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We have a built-in validation layer that stops any bad data from entering your system and OneSchema will notify your team immediately of any data that looks incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Christina Gilbert
quotes.context: An actionable methodology: prevent bad inputs at the boundary and alert quickly to reduce integration-driven distractions.

quotes.topic_title: Manual concierge onboarding teaser
quotes.text: So for folks that don't know, in those early days we insisted on one-to-one concierge onboarding, and it was absolutely the right thing to do.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A clear endorsement of high-touch 1:1 onboarding as a deliberate early-stage growth/product tactic.

quotes.topic_title: Manual concierge onboarding teaser
quotes.text: You couldn't use Superhuman unless you went through the onboarding experience.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A counterintuitive gating mechanism that forces activation and ensures users learn the product correctly.

quotes.topic_title: Manual concierge onboarding teaser
quotes.text: Now it's almost the reverse. Almost every new Superhuman customer goes through self-service.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: Shows an evolution model: start high-touch to nail activation, then transition to scalable self-serve once the playbook is proven.

quotes.topic_title: Manual concierge onboarding teaser
quotes.text: To answer your question, at peak we had about 20 people doing manual onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Rahul Vohra
quotes.context: A concrete scaling data point illustrating the operational investment required to make concierge onboarding work.
